body.p: Nay , tiny shell-bird , What a huge vast inanimate it is , that you must row against , What an incalculable inertia .

lg.l: All animate creation on your shoulder ,
Set forth , little Titan , under your battle-shield .
And you are slowly moving , pioneer , you alone .

body.p: How vivid your travelling seems now , in the troubled sunshine , Stoic , Ulyssean atom ; Suddenly hasty , reckless , on high toes .

lg.l: Resting your head half out of your wimple
In the slow dignity of your eternal pause .
Alone , with no sense of being alone ,
And hence six times more solitary ;
Fulfilled of the slow passion of pitching through
Your little round house in the midst of chaos .
Over the edge of all things .
With your tail tucked a little on one side
Like a gentleman in a long-skirted coat .
All life carried on your shoulder ,
Goes deeper in than we know ,
Along the back of the baby tortoise
The scales are locked in an arch like a bridge ,
Five , and five again , and five again ,
And round the edges twenty-five little ones ,
The sections of the baby tortoise shell .

body.p: His mother deposited him on the soil as if he were no more than droppings , And now he scuffles tinily past her as if she were an old rusty tin .

lg.l: He veers round the slow great mound of her .

body.p: It is no use my saying to him in an emotional voice : “ This is your Mother , she laid you when you were an egg . ”

Row on then , small pebble , Over the clods of the autumn , wind-chilled sunshine , Young gayety .

lg.l: Does he look for a companion ?
No , no , do n't think it .
He does n't know he is alone ;
To row forward , and reach himself tall on spiny

To move , and to be quite sure that he is moving :
Think of it , in a garden of inert clods
A brisk , brindled little tortoise , all to himself —
In a garden of pebbles and insects
To roam , and feel the slow heart beat
From the warm blood , in the dark-creation

She is large and matronly And rather dirty , A little sardonic-looking , as if domesticity had driven her to it .
Though what she does , except lay four eggs at random in the garden once a year And put up with her husband , I do n't know .

body.p: She hurries up , striding reared on long uncanny legs , When food is going . Oh yes , she can make haste when she likes .

lg.l: She snaps the soft bread from my hand in great
Opening her rather pretty wedge of an iron ,
And gulping at more than she can swallow , and
And having the bread hanging over her chin .
Your eye is very dark , very bright ,
She knows well enough to come for food ,
Her bright eye sees , but not me , not anything ,

body.p: Taking bread in her curved , gaping , toothless mouth , She has no qualm when she catches my finger in her steel overlapping gums , But she hangs on , and my shout and my shrinking are nothing to her , She does not even know she is nipping me with her curved beak . Snake-like she draws at my finger , while I drag it in horror away .

lg.l: You are almost too large , I am almost frightened .
Her laconic eye has an earthy , materialistic look ,
